revision.text:
{{for|the American geopolitical strategist|George Friedman}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Georges P. Friedmann | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date |1902|5|13|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Paris]] | death_date = {{death date and age |1977|11|15 |1902|5|13|df=y}} | death_place = Paris | nationality = [[France|French]] | fields = [[Sociology]] | workplaces = | alma_mater =[[École Normale Supérieure]]
[[University of Paris]] | doctoral_advisor = | doctoral_students = | known_for =Labor sociology, technical civilization | influences = [[Leibniz]], [[Spinoza]], [[Karl Marx]], [[Lenin]], [[Lucien Febvre]], [[Karl Jaspers]] | awards = | spouse = | partner = }} '''Georges Philippe Friedmann''' ({{IPA-fr|fʁidman|lang}}; 13 May 1902 – 15 November 1977), was a French sociologist and philosopher, known for his influential work on the effects of industrial labor on individuals and his criticisms of the uncontrolled embrace of technological change in twentieth-century Europe and the United States. == Biography == Friedmann was the last child of Adolphe Friedmann (1857-1922), a Berlin merchant, and Elizabeth Nathan (1871-1940). He was born in Paris, where his parents moved after their marriage in Berlin in 1882. They acquired French nationality in 1903. After a brief period studying industrial chemistry, Friedmann prepared for the philosophy ''[[agrégation]]'' at the prestigious [[Lycée Henri-IV|Lycée Henri IV]] in Paris. He studied philosophy at the [[École Normale Supérieure]] from 1923-1926. He served as an assistant to the sociologist [[Célestin Bouglé]] at the Centre de documentation sociale, a social science research center at the ENS funded by the banker [[Albert Kahn (banker)|Albert Kahn]] and, later, the [[Rockefeller Foundation]]. Upon the death of his father in 1929, Friedmann inherited a fortune of 2.6 million francs, which enabled him to finance several of his young classmates' intellectual journals.{{Cite journal|last=Lallement|first=Michel|date=2014|title=Georges Friedmann au Cnam (1946-1959)|url=http://technique-societe.cnam.fr/medias/fichier/chc1-2014-1_1422283474502-pdf?pk_campaign=chc|journal=Cahiers du CNAM|volume=1|pages=43–74|via=}} Friedmann eventually donated a large part of the fortune to the [[Curie Institute (Paris)|Fondation Curie]] for cancer research. After his death, Degas paintings Friedmann had inherited from his father's collection were donated to the [[Louvre]]. Friedmann married his first wife, Hania Olszweska, a Polish Catholic, in 1937. The couple had one daughter, Liliane, born in 1941 in Toulouse. After Hania's death in 1957, Friedmann married Marcelle Rémond in 1960.{{Cite journal|last=Reynaud|first=Jean-Daniel|date=1994|title=FRIEDMANN, Georges (1902-1977). Professeur d'Histoire du travail (1946-1959)|url=https://www.persee.fr/doc/inrp_0298-5632_1994_ant_19_1_8449|journal=Bibliothèque Historique de l'Éducation|volume=19|pages=544–549|via=Persée}} After taking his family to Toulouse, Friedmann joined the [[French Resistance]] during [[World War II]], when he was hunted by the Nazi [[Gestapo]] due to his Jewish heritage. He later wrote that he escaped the [[Gestapo]] in 1943, and was hidden in a school in [[Dordogne]] by a pair of young schoolteachers.[[Georges Friedmann#cite note-2|[2]]] Friedmann's journals from the war, published posthumously in 1987, recounted his experiences as a member of the resistance. He received his ''Doctorat d'état'' in 1946, with his major thesis on mechanization in industrial production and minor thesis on Leibniz and Spinoza, both published as monographs.{{Cite web|url=http://www.isa-sociology.org/en/about-isa/history-of-isa/isa-past-presidents/list-of-presidents/georges-friedmann/|title=Georges Friedmann|last=|first=|date=|website=International Sociological Association|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} == Scholarly work == At the ENS, Friedmann was close to the Philosophies group that opposed the influence of [[Henri Bergson]] and was influential in bringing Marx’s earlier philosophical texts to France, and included [[Georges Politzer]], [[Norbert Guterman]]n, [[Paul Nizan]], and [[Henri Lefebvre]]. The group's initial journal, ''Esprit,'' and its successor, ''Philosophies'', were funded by Friedmann's personal wealth.{{Cite book|title=French Marxism Between the Wars: Henri Lefebvre and the Philosophies|last=Burkhard|first=Bud|publisher=Humanity Books|year=2000|isbn=|location=Amherst, NY|pages=26}} During the 1930s, Friedmann made several trips to the [[Soviet Union]], where observed the Soviet industry and technology. His 1938 book, ''De la Sainte Russie à l’U.R.S.S.'' established him as an authority on Soviet society in France. But even his moderate criticisms of the U.S.S.R. and [[Joseph Stalin|Stalin]] caused bitter conflict with members of the [[French Communist Party]] and began Friedmann’s move away from political activism.{{Cite journal|last=Gouarné|first=Isabelle|title=Engagement philosoviétique et posture sociologique dans l'entre-deux-guerres : le rôle politico-intellectuel de Georges Friedmann|journal=Sociologie du Travail|volume=54|issue=3|pages=356–374|doi=10.1016/j.soctra.2012.06.002|year=2012}} Friedmann’s doctoral thesis, published after the end of the war in 1946, examined the "human problems" of automation and mechanization European industrial production. A critical, historical overview of paradigms of industrial management, particularly [[scientific management]], [[Industrial and organizational psychology|industrial psychology]], and [[Human relations movement|human relations]], ''Problèmes humains du machinisme industriel'' examined social scientists’ efforts to "humanize" industrial labor that had been fragmented and [[Deskilling|de-skilled]] by industrialization and Taylorism. Friedmann argued that while these efforts were an improvement on the "technicist ideology" of management engineering, social science would not lead to significant changes in labor practices without class conflict and the transformation of the capitalist economic system.{{Cite book|title=Problèmes humains du machinisme industriel|last=Friedmann|first=Georges|publisher=Gallimard|year=1946|isbn=978-2070225897|location=Paris|pages=381–388}} Friedmann’s book is considered a founding text of French ''sociologie du travail'', and his seminar influenced a number of younger sociologists, historians, and philosophers, including [[Edgar Morin]] and [[Alain Touraine]].{{Cite book|title=Servants of post-industrial power? : sociologie du travail in Modern France|last=1937-|first=Rose, Michael,|date=1979|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=9780333236499}} While holding various professorships and serving as the head of the French [[Centre national de la recherche scientifique]] (CNRS), Friedmann continued to travel extensively around the world, observing and publishing on labor practices and industrial models in the United States, Israel, and South America. His analysis of the nature of the Jewish people and Israeli society in ''The End of the Jewish People''?, one of his few works to be translated into English, attracted media attention in the United States.{{Cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9905E7D7113AE63ABC4152DFB166838C679EDE&legacy=true|title=Victory, or Defeat?|last=Lask|first=Thomas|date=July 19, 1967|work=The New York Times|access-date=June 6, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}} Friedmann gradually shifted from emphasis on labor to a broader concern with "technical civilization." His final book, ''La Puissance et la Sagesse'', a mixture of autobiography and reflection on contemporary society, modified his earlier Marxism and emphasized the importance of interiority and morality on humanizing postwar consumer society.{{Cite book|url=http://books.openedition.org/editionscnrs/1669|title=Georges Friedmann : Un sociologue dans le siècle, 1902-1977|last=Segrestin|first=Denis|publisher=CNRS Editions|year=2013|isbn=|editor-last=Grémion|editor-first=Pierre|location=Paris|pages=141–152|chapter=«La Puissance et la Sagesse» : Georges Friedmann face à la civilisation technicienne}} ==Bibliography== *''La Crise du progrès: esquisse d'histoire des idées, 1895-1935'' (Paris: Gallimard, 1936) *''De la Sainte Russie à l'U.R.S.S.'' (Paris: Gallimard, 1938) *''Problèmes humains du machinisme industriel'' (Paris: Gallimard, 1946) **''Industrial Society: The Emergence of Human Problems of Automation'' (Glencoe, Ill.: Free Press, 1955) *''Où va le travail humain?'' (Paris: Gallimard, 1950) *''Le travail en miettes'' (Paris: Gallimard, 1956) **''The Anatomy of Work: Labor, Leisure, and the Implications of Automation'', trans. Wyatt Watson (Glencoe, Ill: Free Press, 1961) *''Problèmes d'Amérique latine'' (Paris: Gallimard, 1959) * ''Signal d'une troisième voie?'' (Paris: Gallimard, 1961) * ''Fin du peuple juif? ''(Paris: Gallimard, 1965) ** ''The End of the Jewish People?'' (New York: Doubleday, 1967) * ''Sept études sur l'homme et la technique: Le pourquoi et le pour quoi de notre civilisation technicienne'' (Paris: Gonthier, 1966) *''La Puissance et la Sagesse'' (Paris: Gallimard, 1970) * ''Journal de Guerre (1939-1940)'' (Paris: Gallimard, 1987) * ''Ces merveilleux instruments: Essais sur la communication de masse'' (Paris: Denoël-Gonthier, 1988) == Further reading == * Gremion et Piotet, eds. ''[http://books.openedition.org/editionscnrs/1637 Georges Friedmann: Un sociologue dans le siècle: 1902-1977.]'' Paris: CNRS Editions, 2014. * Vatin, François. "[http://www.mhh.domainepublic.net/SALARIADO/maquinismo_marxismo_(vatin).pdf Machinisme, marxisme, humanisme: Georges Friedmann avant et après-guerre]." ''Sociologie du Travail'' no. 46 (2004), 205-223. * Vatin, François and Rot, Gwenaële. "[https://www.cairn.info/revue-geneses-2004-4-p-23.htm Les avatars du travail à la chaîne dans l'ouvre de Georges Friedmann]." ''Genèses'' 4, no. 57 (2004), 23-40. ==External links== * [https://www.jstor.org/action/doAdvancedSearch?si=1&Query=au%3A%22Georges+Friedmann%22&f0=au&c4=AND&f1=all&c3=AND&f2=all&f5=all&c5=AND&group=none&acc=on&c1=AND&c2=AND&f4=all&c6=AND&f6=all&f3=all&q0=Georges+Friedmann&refreqid=search%3Ab8d4827d8e Articles by Georges Friedmann on JSTOR] (French) * [http://www.isa-sociology.org/en/about-isa/history-of-isa/isa-past-presidents/list-of-presidents/georges-friedmann/ Biography at the International Sociological Association] ==References== {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Friedmann, Georges}} [[Category:French Jews]] [[Category:French sociologists]] [[Category:Jewish philosophers]] [[Category:1902 births]] [[Category:1977 deaths]] [[Category:École Normale Supérieure alumni]] [[Category:Lycée Henri-IV alumni]] [[Category:French male writers]] [[Category:Sociology]] [[Category:Marxism]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/223.187.237.229|223.187.237.229]] ([[User talk:223.187.237.229|talk]]): unexplained content removal ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.4)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=June 2018}} {{primary sources|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox magazine | image_file = Gobar_Times_Pandit.jpg | image_caption = First Issue, May, 1998 | frequency = Monthly | category = Children's Environment Magazine | company = [[Centre for Science and Environment]] | firstdate =May 1998 | country = India | based = [[New Delhi]] | language = English | website = [http://www.gobartimes.org Gobar Times] - Official Website [http://www.cseindia.org/ Centre for Science and Environment]- Official Website }} '''''Gobar Times''''' is a monthly environmental education magazine for the young adult, published by the [[Centre for Science and Environment]]. It is published along with ''[[Down to Earth (magazine)|Down to Earth]]'' as a supplement. The magazine was first published in May, 1998 and has widespread circulation across India and abroad. The icon of the magazine, Pandit Gobar Ganesh, the pondering panditji is an Indian elderly who takes the reader through current issues, subjects and ideas relating to the environment. He is the icon whose brains can be picked for anything on earth. The current editor of the magazine is Sumita Dasgupta.
"[[Gobar]]" is the [[Hindi language|Hindi]] and [[Nepali language|Nepali]] word for "cow dung". It was chosen to capture the eco-philosophy and tradition of generating wealth from waste. Waste gobar serves as an [[insecticide]] and is used to plaster mud houses and is a waterproof coating for walls. It is also used to plaster floors to keep them cool. Gobar is the energy source for rural India. It is used as cooking fuel where people have no access to fuels like [[Liquefied petroleum gas|LPG]]. The greatest use of cow dung in India is in farming where it is used as natural manure for farmers' crops. In short, it's a mainstay of rural India, and an appropriate symbol for eco-friendly technology.
[[Anil Agarwal (environmentalist)|Anil Agarwal]] the founder-director of Centre for Science and Environment, India’s leading environmental NGO, aptly called ‘Gobar’ the symbol that embodies the spirit of the Indian environmental movement. As he correctly reflected, the widespread and diverse use of gobar in Indian society stands up to every principle of good environmentalism.
== History == In May 1992, the Society for Environmental Communications started India’s only science and environment fortnightly, ''Down To Earth'' (DTE). Over the years the magazine has informed and inspired people about environmental threats facing India and the world - a dimension underplayed in mainstream media. In May, 1998, ''Gobar Times'' was first published as a supplement to ''DTE''. ''Gobar Times'' reaches out to the young, encouraging them to take the lead and make a difference. It informs them and encourages them to save the environment by becoming an action-oriented, knowledgeable and aware community. The tone of the magazine is light-hearted, simple and thought-provoking. Every month the magazine comes up with an activity related center spread which can be pulled out and put up as a poster to encourage readers to become active participants. The magazine has recently entered into a partnership with the leading newspaper ''[[Hindustan Times]]''. Readers can now get a glimpse of what Pandit Gobar Ganesh has to say as they read HTNext.
== Green Schools Program == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:GSP-logo.gif|thumb|left|GSP logo]] -->Conceptualized by the [[New Delhi]]–based Centre for Science and Environment(CSE), The ''Gobar Times'' Green Schools Program allows self-assessment of the environmental practices of a school by its students, using the "Green Schools Manual". This inspection or survey of environmental practices at schools<ref>[http://www.gdsalwan.com/Environment.html G D Salwan Public School, Green Schools Program]</ref><ref>[http://www.kfirural.org/Green_sch.html The Rural centre]</ref> is a way for them to audit their immediate environment across the key areas of water, air, land, energy and waste.
*'''Water''': To make the school water literate and teach ways of [[rainwater harvesting]] and recycling of waste water. *'''Air''': Students check out the transport system of the school and understand how people commute to school. This further enables them to understand how transport policies affect air quality and how they can innovate and find ways of reducing [[Air pollution|emissions]]. *'''Land''': The different plant and animal species on the school campus are identified by the students and a survey done on the use of [[pesticides]] in the school. Understanding the concept of carrying capacity. *'''Energy''': The students study electricity and other forms of energy consumption on the school campus and explore ways in which it can be minimized. *'''Waste''': Students find out how much and what type of waste the school is producing? Learn [[composting]] and waste segregation methods in the process.
By the end of it all the program gives the students an opportunity to give a report card to the school on its environmental performance and practices. They conduct the audit with the help of an interesting handbook called the 'Green Schools Program Manual' (2007 Edition). This manual gives them step by step guidelines on how to conduct an environmental audit in the school.
The purpose of the Green Schools Program is to encourage and support schools to build up an environmentally aware, active and skilled community<ref>[http://www.hindu.com/2007/01/09/stories/2007010902810800.htm Opinion, Director - NCERT]</ref> of teachers, students and parents. The schools may use the manual as part of their environmental studies program or to conduct activities in eco-clubs. The data collected by students is compiled and rated such that it becomes a self-assessment tool of environmental practices followed by the school. The aim of the rating is, to understand what can be done to improve the schools performance on its environmental sustainability index and to implement changes over the coming years.
=== Awards === The ''Gobar Times'' Green Schools Awards is a platform to acknowledge and reward schools which have adopted the most innovative and effective practices to manage [[natural resources]] within their own premises. Schools send in their green reports to CSE. These reports undergo rigorous verification and selection and the best schools are awarded annually.<ref>[http://news.outlookindia.com/item.aspx?650467 Outlook Magazine]</ref><ref>[http://www.indianexpress.com/news/delhi-schools-awarded-for-green-initiatives/582368/ Indian Express - Green Initiative]</ref><ref>[http://www.hindu.com/2010/02/21/stories/2010022158190300.htm The Hindu - Elite 'Delhi' schools fail 'green test']</ref>
[[File:Award GSP.jpg|thumb|left|Award ceremony for Green Schools Program]]
The top 10 schools of the country which have been working and have implemented tremendous improvement in their environmental practices are awarded the 'Change Makers' award. Schools participating for the first time are considered in the 'New Schools' category.<ref>[http://www.stpauls-delhi.com/parents%20corner.html St Pauls, Delhi]</ref> They are judged basis involvement of students and teachers, and the quality of the reports submitted. Also schools which do not necessarily audit all areas but do exceptionally well in a single specific area of water, energy, land, air or waste apply for the coveted 'Best Managers' award.
=== Partners === The [[National Green Corps]]<ref>[[National Green Corps#External links|National Green Corps]]</ref> is a program of the [[Ministry of Environment and Forests (India)|Ministry of Environment and Forest]], Government of India). State nodal offices and CSE partner in many states across India. As the Green Schools network is expanding, the awards are now also organized at the state level.<ref>[http://www.pscst.com/en/about/CSE%20green%20school%20award.htm Punjab State, Green Schools Program]</ref><ref>[http://www.sikenvis.nic.in/archives.htm Sikkim, Green Schools Training]</ref> The highest rank holders at the state level in different categories are nominated by state nodal agencies to compete for national awards with CSE in Delhi.
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.gobartimes.org Gobar Times] - Official Website * [http://www.cseindia.org/ Centre for Science and Environment]- Official Website

Frisque (President, 1977)|Barrie M. Phillips (Vice president, Director of Research, 1977-1978; President, 1978-1979)|Yvonne Bonahoom (President)}} | industry = | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = {{unbulleted list|Dr. Joseph C. Calandra (1953-1966)|[[Nalco Holding Company]] (1966-)}} | num_employees = 350 | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Industrial Bio-Test Laboratories''' ('''IBT Labs''') was an [[United States|American]] industrial product safety testing laboratory.{{cite journal | title = The murky world of toxicity testing | journal = Science | date = 1983-06-10 | first = Eliot | last = Marshall | volume = 220 | issue = 4602 | pages = 1130–1132 | bibcode = 1983Sci...220.1130M | url = http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/lnn13c00/pdf | format = PDF | accessdate = 2012-07-27 | pmid=6857237 | doi=10.1126/science.6857237}}{{cite news | first = Keith | last = Schneider | title = U.S. Seeks to Learn if Tests On Pesticides Were Falsified | date = 1991-03-02 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/02/us/us-seeks-to-learn-if-tests-on-pesticides-were-falsified.html | work = The New York Times | accessdate = 2012-07-11 | quote = Three top executives of the laboratory, Industrial Bio-Test Laboratories, were indicted and convicted in 1983 for claims that they had conducted safety tests on pesticides when, in fact, they had not.}} IBT conducted significant quantities of research for pharmaceutical companies, chemical manufacturers and other industrial clients; at its height during the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s, IBT operated the largest facility of its kind and performed more than one-third of all [[toxicology testing]] in the [[United States]].{{cite news | first = Keith | last = Schneider | title = Science; Lab Fraud - or Government Harassment | date = 1983-04-03 | work = The Boston Globe }}{{cite book | last1 = Carson | first1 = Phillip A. | last2 = Dent | first2 = N. | title = Good Clinical, Laboratory and Manufacturing Practices | publisher = Royal Society of Chemistry | date = 2007-06-01 | pages = 172–174 | isbn = 978-0854048342}}{{cite web | url = http://www.westgard.com/guest16.htm | title = Good Laboratory Practice versus CLIA | accessdate = 2012-07-12 | last = Cook | first = Janine Denis | work = University of Maryland, Baltimore}} IBT was later confirmed of engaging in extensive [[scientific misconduct]], or more properly, fraud, which resulted in the indictment of its president and several top executives in 1981 and convictions in 1983.{{cite news | first = Doug | last = Foster | title = Industrial Bio-Test Lab's Dirty Research | date = 1983-12-07 | publisher = [[Center for Investigative Reporting]] | url = http://mail.centerforinvestigativereporting.org/articles/industrialbiotestlabsdirtyresearch | work = Oakland Tribune | accessdate = 2012-07-11}} The revelations of misconduct by IBT Labs led to reforms in the regulation of pesticides in the United States and Canada. ==History== ===Early years=== IBT was founded in 1953 by Dr. Joseph C. Calandra, an [[Italian American]] professor of [[pathology]] and [[biochemistry]] at [[Northwestern University]].{{cite book | last1 = Gribbin | first1 = John H. | last2 = Krogfus | first2 = Sue Singer | editor1-first=Dina E. | editor1-last=Van Bavel | editor2-first=Walter M. | editor2-last=Whitlow | editor3-first=Lee | editor3-last=Michelson | editor4-first=Frank M. |display-editors = 3 | editor4-last=Holz | title = Industrial research laboratories of the United States | volume = Publication 844 | edition = 11 | publisher = National Academy of Sciences—National Research Council | year = 1960 | location = Washington, D.C. | pages = 256 }}{{cite news | first = Shia | last = Kapos | title = Dr. Joseph C. Calandra, 84 | date = 2002-03-12 | url = http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2002-03-12/news/0203120033_1_independent-testing-labs-toxicology-products | work = Chicago Tribune | accessdate = 2012-07-16}} Calandra, the first of his family to pursue [[higher education]], contributed to the concept of [[virtually safe dose|toxicologically innocuous dose]]s during his [[tenure]] at Northwestern. Described by his colleagues as a "man of high scientific standards who also knew how to make a dollar", Calandra was an effective entrepreneur; his laboratory was contracted by the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] to evaluate [[Food irradiation|irradiationally]] [[food preservation|preserved food]] within its first year of operation.{{cite news | first = Keith | last = Schneider | title = The rise and fall of IBT | date = 1983-05-11 | url = http://www.unz.org/Pub/InTheseTimes-1983may11-00003 | work = In These Times | pages = 3 | accessdate = 2012-07-16}}{{cite journal | title = Whose Studies Should You Believe? | journal = Science for the People | date = March–April 1986 | volume = 18 | issue = 2 | pages = 15 | url = http://socrates.berkeley.edu/~schwrtz/SftP/MagazineArchive/SftPv18n2s.pdf | accessdate = 2012-07-19}} By 1960, IBT reported that its professional staff included 12 biologists, five chemists, a mathematician, four physicians and a veterinarian, and that it employed 16 technicians. Calandra was president and director and John H. Kay was the associate director. At that time, it listed its research areas as "industrial toxicology, food, drugs, cosmetics, pharmacology, radioisotopes, medical, dental, and veterinary products". By the early 1960s, IBT had attained a significant reputation for producing quality work at a reasonable price.{{cite news | first = William J. | last = Broad | title = Who Tests the Product-Testing Labs? | date = 1983-05-22 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/22/weekinreview/who-tests-the-product-testing-labs.html | work = The New York Times | accessdate = 2012-07-11}} As of mid-decade, it had annual revenue estimated at nearly $2 million US. ===1966–1970: Nalco acquisition, expansion=== [[Nalco Holding Company|Nalco Chemical]] acquired IBT in 1966 for an estimated $4.5 million. Utilizing the company's new financial prowess, Calandra oversaw considerable expansion of the company and constructed two new facilities. IBT began conducting tests on [[Polychlorinated biphenyl|polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs)]] in 1969.{{cite news | first = Robert | last = Steyer | title = Lab Falsified Monsanto PCB Data, Witness Says | date = 1991-10-29 | work = St. Louis Post-Dispatch }} In 1970, Calandra began construction of a large $2 million laboratory and made two executive appointments: Dr. Moreno Keplinger as Manager of Toxicology and James Plank as Group Lead of Rat Toxicology. ===1971–1976: Eminence=== In March 1971, IBT hired Dr. Paul L. Wright, one of [[Monsanto]]'s [[toxicologist]]s, to oversee its PCB testing.{{cite journal | title = Weed Killer | journal = The Progressive | date = July 1987 | first = Kimery | last = Anthony L. | pages = 20–21 }} Dr. Donovan E. Gordon joined IBT as a [[pathologist]] in August 1971, and IBT finalized its safety analysis of PCBs in November 1971. Irregularities in IBT's data were discovered in April 1976 by Adrian Gross, an investigator at the [[Food and Drug Administration]], whose aide retrieved one of the laboratory's [[naproxen]] studies that had been conducted for [[Syntex]], a pharmaceutical company recently outed by a [[whistleblower]].Laboratory Accused of Fudging [https://www.nytimes.com/1981/06/28/weekinreview/ideas-trends-in-summary-laboratory-official-accused-of-fudging.html?scp=216&sq=Deodorant&st=nyt NY Times]{{cite journal | title = The Industrial Bio-Test Caper | journal = NCAP News | date = Winter 1981 | first = Paul | last = Merrell | volume = 2 | issue = 3 | pages = 2–4 | url = http://www.pesticide.org/get-the-facts/ncap-publications-and-reports/journal-of-pesticide-reform/jpr-vol.2-3-winter-1981.pdf | accessdate = 2012-08-05}} Gross nonetheless continued to read IBT's study, which would ineluctably strike him as being unrealistic and pique his interest. The FDA proceeded to probe IBT, and Gross personally inspected its facilities on April 11 and July 12, 1976.{{cite journal | title = Lab admits to defects in toxicity studies | journal = Chemical & Engineering News | date = 1977-07-11 | volume = 55 | issue = 28 | pages = 7 | doi=10.1021/cen-v055n028.p007}}{{cite court | litigants = United States of America, Plaintiff-appellee, v. Joseph C. Calandra, Moreno Keplinger, Paul L. Wright, and James B. Plank, Defendants-appellants | vol = 706 | reporter = F.2d | opinion = 225 | court = 7th Cir. | date = 1983-05-03 | url = http://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/c/F2/706/706.F2d.225.83-1586.83-1583.html}} During Gross' physical inspection of the laboratory, he gained access to the study's raw safety data and found frequent references to an unknown acronym, "TBD/TDA," which he said perplexed him until learning that it denoted a testing animal whose body had "too badly decomposed."{{cite news | first = William | last = Inman | title = Agents stumble onto massive fraud | date = 1984-02-19 | work = The Salina Journal | pages = 21 }} ===1977–1983: Investigation, indictment, notoriety=== Revelations of suspected scientific misconduct would go on to be presented in March 1977 at [[United States Senate Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions|Senate Subcommittee on Health and Scientific Research]] hearings held by [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Ted Kennedy]] (D-MA), in which the integrity of safety data produced by IBT, as well as [[G. D. Searle & Company]] and Biometric Testing, Inc., was publicly called into question by FDA officials.{{cite journal | title = Poisoned Research | journal = Mother Jones | date = June 1982 | first = Douglas | last = Foster |author2=Mark Dowie |author3=Steve Hubbell |author4=Irene Moosen |author5=Peter Waldman |author6=Center for Investigative Reporting | volume = 7 | issue = 5 | pages = 38–40, 42–43, 45–48 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=nuYDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA37 | accessdate = 2012-07-28}}{{cite news | first = Morton | last = Mintz | title = Indictment Accuses Drug-Testing Firm of Falsifying Results | date = 1979-06-01 | work = The Washington Post }} Calandra vacated his role as president of the laboratory on March 25 and was succeeded by A. J. Frisque, who had previously worked as a research executive at Nalco.{{cite news | title = People and Business; Calandra Out as Bio-Test Head; Concern Under Study by F.D.A. | date = 1977-03-26 | work = The New York Times }} Plank parted ways with IBT in April, and Philip Smith, who would later testify against the laboratory, was "fired and given 20 minutes to clean out his office" in approximately June 1977. That same month, on June 2, IBT would also shred more of its internal documents, an action which Frisque characterized in a subsequent official statement as being "entirely inadvertent."{{cite journal | title = Toxicology lab defends document shredding | journal = Chemical & Engineering News | date = 1977-09-26 | volume = 55 | issue = 39 | pages = 7 | doi=10.1021/cen-v055n039.p007a}} IBT was criminally implicated in 1977 for producing fraudulent studies on widely used household and industrial products, including Nemacur, [[Sencor]], [[naproxen|Naprosyn]], and [[trichlorocarbanilide]].{{cite journal|title=Faking It: The Case against Industrial Bio-Test Laboratories |journal=The Amicus Journal |date=Spring 1993 |first=Keith |last=Schneider |publisher=[[Natural Resources Defense Council]] |url=http://planetwaves.net/contents/faking_it.html |accessdate=2012-07-14 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69A19G61r?url=http://planetwaves.net/contents/faking_it.html |archivedate=2012-07-14 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite news | title = Former Lab Worker Queried on Altered Data | date = 1983-05-15 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/15/us/former-lab-worker-queried-on-altered-data.html | work = The New York Times | accessdate = 2012-07-20}} The magnitude of IBT's [[scientific misconduct]] was considered to have been extensive: 618 of 867 (71%) of studies audited by the FDA were invalidated for having "numerous discrepancies between the study conduct and data."{{cite news | first = Keith | last = Schneider | title = IBT Labs' trial reveals faked data | date = 1983-05-11 | url = http://www.unz.org/Pub/InTheseTimes-1983may11-00003 | work = In These Times | pages = 3, 6 | accessdate = 2012-07-16}} Consequently, IBT would later be described as being "at the center of one of the most far-reaching scandals in modern science, as thousands of its studies were revealed through EPA and FDA investigations to be fraudulent or grossly inadequate."{{cite journal | title = Pandora's poison | journal = Sierra | date = September–October 1994 | first = Eric Francis | last = Coppolino | authorlink = Eric Francis | editor-first=Paul | editor-last=Rauber | editor-link = Paul Rauber |author2=Hilary Lanner |author3=Brenda Shawley | volume = 79 | issue = 5 | pages = 40 | url = http://www.sierraclub.org/sierra/200103/conspiracy.asp | accessdate = 2012-07-12}} Although the criminal case against IBT and its employees was proceeding, information about which chemicals were "suspect" because of IBT's misconduct was kept confidential by the Canadian and American government agencies responsible to regulating them.{{cite news | first = Peter| last = von Stackelberg| title = The Toxic Mist: The Use and Abuse of Pesticides | date = November 1980 | publisher = [[Regina Leader-Post]]}}{{Page needed|date=February 2013}} In early 1980 the Regina Leader-Post obtained a Canadian government agency{{which|date=February 2013}} list of 106 chemicals about which there were concerns.{{Page needed|date=February 2013}} The Regina Leader-Post also obtained a letter written Jan. 25, 1980 by R.O. Read, who was Chief of the Division of Additives and Pesticides in the Bureau of Chemical Safety Health Protection, a Branch of Canada's Health and Welfare Department, to, {{Who|date=February 2013}} that said: "All long-term rodent studies and multigenerational reproductive studies performed by IBT are considered invalid," and noted that the Canadian government had sent letters to a number of chemical companies pointing out that many had "failed to submit the information required by the Environmental Protection Agency and the Canadian health protection branch."{{Page needed|date=February 2013}} Documentation obtained from a variety of Canadian and American sources{{which|date=February 2013}} by the Regina Leader-Post included sloppy or inadequate record keeping that invalidated test results. In a number of cases, sick test animals were replaced with healthy ones, resulting in invalid test results.{{Page needed|date=February 2013}} In October 1983, three former officials of the company were convicted by a US federal jury of fabricating key product safety tests used to gain government approval for marketing two popular pesticides and two commonly used drugs.{{cite journal|title=IBT – Guilty |journal=Amicus Journal |date=Winter 1983 |first=Keith |last=Schneider |url=http://planetwaves.net/contents/ibt_guity.html |accessdate=2012-07-19 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69H25Lrgw?url=http://planetwaves.net/contents/ibt_guity.html |archivedate=2012-07-19 |deadurl=yes |df= }} They were convicted after one of the longest criminal trials in US history, involving six months of testimony and nearly eleven days of jury deliberation. At the time it was regarded as "the most massive scientific scandal in the history of this country and perhaps the world." The decision was subsequently appealed and upheld in ''United States of America v. Moreno L. Keplinger, Paul L. Wright, and James B. Plank''.{{cite book | last1 = Clinard | first1 = Marshall Barron | title = Corporate Corruption: The Abuse of Power | publisher = Greenwood Publishing Group | year = 1990 | pages = 63 | isbn = 978-0275934859}}{{cite court | litigants = United States of America, Plaintiff-appellee, v. Moreno L. Keplinger, Paul L. Wright, and James B. Plank, Defendants-appellants | vol = 776 | reporter = F.2d | opinion = 678 | court = 7th Cir. | date = 1985-10-29 | url = http://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F2/776/678/443220/}}{{cite web | url = http://www.monsanto.com/products/Documents/glyphosate-background-materials/ibt_craven_bkg.pdf | title = Backgrounder: Testing Fraud: IBT and Craven Laboratories | publisher = [[Monsanto]] | accessdate = 2012-07-11 | date = June 2005 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121030132754/http://www.monsanto.com/products/Documents/glyphosate-background-materials/ibt_craven_bkg.pdf | archivedate = 2012-10-30 | df = }} ==Federal trial== Following the 1981 [[Grand juries in the United States|grand jury]] indictment of several key IBT officials, a federal trial began on April 4, 1983 to evaluate whether IBT had in fact committed scientific fraud.{{cite journal | title = Pulp Fiction: Reflections on Scientific Misconduct | journal = Wisconsin Law Review | date = 2004-01-05 | first = Bratislav | last = Stankovic | volume = 2004 | issue = 3 | pages = 1002–1010 | ssrn = 2051465 | accessdate = }}{{cite news | title = Lab hid facts, ex-worker says | date = 1983-05-27 | publisher = [[Wilmington Morning Star]] | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JsgsAAAAIBAJ&pg=2715,3051837 | work = Associated Press | accessdate = 2012-07-23}}{{cite news | title = Illinois Case Mistrial Declared | date = 1983-07-12 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/12/us/illinois-case-mistrial-declared.html | work = The New York Times | pages = A15 | accessdate = 2012-07-27}} According to a May 13 article in ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', "investigators charged that three big chemical companies—[[[Monsanto]], [[Olin Corporation]], and [[FMC Corporation]]]—knowingly submitted flawed data to the EPA in support of a widely used swimming pool chlorinator that was suspected of causing kidney and bladder problems."{{cite news | title = Trial of Former IBT Officers Raises Product-Safety Doubts | date = 1983-05-13 | work = The Wall Street Journal }} All three companies denied allegations of wrongdoing and reaffirmed the safety of their products.{{cite news | title = FMC Corp. Says Bio-Test Data Was Submitted In 'Good Faith' | date = 1983-05-13 | work = The Wall Street Journal }}{{cite news | title = Monsanto Denies Allegations It Used Flawed Test Data | date = 1983-05-13 | work = The Wall Street Journal }} On May 25, Cornelius Garrett testified that "[no] research animals survived the entire testing period" for either Sencor or Nemacure.{{cite news | title = Employee Testifies In Research Fraud Case | date = 1983-05-27 | publisher = [[Daytona Beach Morning Journal]] | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cYgfAAAAIBAJ&pg=1862,5712101 | work = Associated Press | accessdate = 2012-07-26}} Garrett also testified that Smith instructed him to falsify subject data, which he said was a "common practice".{{cite news | title = Credibility of a Key Witness Assailed at Trial on Lab Tests | date = 1983-06-01 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/01/us/credibility-of-a-key-witness-assailed-at-trial-on-lab-tests.html | work = The New York Times | pages = A17 | accessdate = 2012-07-20}} Smith testified that he was himself instructed by Wright to similarly falsify data on [[Triclocarban|trichlorocarbanilide]] tests.{{cite news | title = Ex-Aide in Laboratory Says Data on Soap Ingredient were Falsified | date = 1983-05-09 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/09/us/ex-aide-in-laboratory-says-data-on-soap-ingredient-were-falsified.html | work = The New York Times | pages = A17 | accessdate = 2012-07-20}} Calandra requested a mistrial to have [[cardiac surgery]] and received approval on July 11.{{cite news | title = Trial of Testing Aides To Proceed, Judge Rules | date = 1983-07-13 | work = The New York Times }} Keplinger, Plank and Wright resultingly argued that they should also receive a mistrial because his absence would undermine their case, but their request was denied on July 12. Testimony included that of an attorney retained by Nalco to defend IBT, Merrill Thompson, who refused to participate during earlier investigations of the laboratory. "As I got into it and worked on these things more, and found out more, and worked with IBT people more, and looked at the evidence of other practices in the industry, I decided I couldn't defend IBT's practices," Thompson testified.{{cite news | title = Trial Ending for 3 over Lab Safety Research | date = 1983-09-25 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/25/us/trial-ending-for-3-over-lab-safety-research.html | work = The New York Times | accessdate = 2012-07-27}} Testimony drew to a close on September 22. [[Closing argument]]s concluded on October 4 and juror [[deliberation]] ensued.{{cite news | title = Jury Gets Chicago Lab Case | date = 1983-10-05 | work = The New York Times }} The case was decided by [[John Albert Nordberg]] on October 21, 1983.{{cite news | title = 3 Guilty of Faking Drug-Test Results | date = 1983-10-22 | work = The Philadelphia Inquirer | pages = A05 }}{{cite news | title = 3-Ex Officials of Major Laboratory Convicted of Falsifying Drug Tests | date = 1983-10-22 | work = The New York Times }} ==Aftermath== The [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) announced on July 11, 1983 that 34 pesticides would be pulled from the market unless manufacturers provided additional safety data within 90 days, although an indefinite exception was made for those who committed to do so at a later time.{{cite news | first = Philip | last = Shabecoff | title = E.P.A. Threatens to Suspend Approval of Pesticides over Test Flaws | date = 1983-07-12 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/12/us/epa-threatens-to-suspend-approval-of-pesticides-over-test-flaws.html | work = The New York Times | accessdate = 2012-07-16}} [[Environmental organization]]s characterized the EPA's response as insufficient and negligent, expressing a desire for more decisive action. In September 1983, the agency revealed that it was still a "long way from solving problems associated with the integrity of hundreds of studies produced by IBT and other large independent laboratories." Keith Schneider reported in the Winter 1983 edition of ''Amicus Journal'' that "IBT performed over 2,000 key product safety tests approved by federal scientists to market 212 agricultural pesticides. After a seven-year review of its files, in 1983 the EPA reported that it had determined that only 16 percent of IBT's testing results were valid. Just a handful of the invalid studies have been replaced, the agency said, and most of the pesticides continue to be sprayed on fields and forests." [[Good Laboratory Practice]] regulation in the United States resulted from the episode.{{cite journal | title = The long arm of the lab laws | journal = Today's Chemist at Work | date = November 2001 | first = Roger A. | last = Novak | url = http://pubs.acs.org/subscribe/archive/tcaw/10/i11/html/11regs.html | accessdate = 2012-07-18}}{{cite news | first = Clare | last = Howard | title = Good Practice v. Good Science | date = 2012-05-31 | url = http://100r.org/2012/05/good-practices-vs-good-science/ | work = 100Reporters | accessdate = 2012-08-13 | quote = A criminal investigation resulted in convictions for three executives of Industrial Bio-Test Laboratories charged with deliberately doctoring data. No academic labs were involved in the scandal, but the GLP standard that emerged is now used by regulators in the United States and Europe. }}{{cite web | url = http://www.pogo.org/pogo-files/reports/public-health/safety-of-medical-devices/ph-fda-20090218.html | title = The FDA's Deadly Gamble with the Safety of Medical Devices | accessdate = 2012-08-13 | date = 2009-02-18 | publisher = [[Project On Government Oversight]]}} The [[Law Commission of Canada|Law Reform Commission of Canada]] noted in a 1987 report that [[Agriculture in Canada|Canadian agriculture]]'s increasing dependence on pesticides had led to inaction against many of those approved on the basis of IBT's research data.{{cite journal | title = Ottawa Accepts Invalid Pesticide Data, Law Commission Says | journal = HEF Canada Quarterly | publisher = Winnipeg Free Press, Human Ecology Foundation | date=1987-10-29 | publication-date = 1987-12-31 | volume = 9 | issue = 4 | pages = 34–35 | url = http://ages.ca/sites/default/files/quarterlydec1987ocr.pdf | accessdate = 2012-07-19 | quote=Many pesticides registered as a result of invalid IBT data are still used in Canada, the study says, because the federal government refused to take them off the market until retesting could be done. "The policy suggests that over the past 20 to 30 years, Canadian agriculture has become so dependent on chemical pesticides to produce food that once some chemicals are registered and used for a period of time, they develop a virtual immunity to remedial regulatory action," the commission says.}} [[Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada|Agriculture Canada]] banned use of [[Diquat|Reglone]] until further safety testing could be conducted and evaluated by [[Health and Welfare Canada]], though application of the chemical continued illegally on a significant majority of [[lentil]]s produced.{{cite news | first = Geoffrey | last = York | title = Risky farm chemical draws warning from government | date = 1988-01-25 | work = The Globe and Mail | pages = B7 }} Chlorbromuron, cyprazine, dinitramine, and [[phosphamidon]] were also banned "because their manufacturers did not promise replacement studies," with Allidochlor and [[Captan]] being restricted.{{cite news | title = Faulty Tests Lead to Canadian Chemical Ban | date = 1983-06-23 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/23/us/faulty-tests-lead-to-canadian-chemical-ban.html | work = The New York Times | pages = A10 | accessdate = 2012-07-27}} ==Clientele== According to various reports, IBT's clientele included a wide variety of companies such as [[3M]], [[American Cyanamid]], American Seed, Avitrol Corp, BFC, Black Leaf Chemical, [[Buckman (company)|Buckman]], [[Casoron]], Chemagro, [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]], [[Novartis|Ciba‑Geigy]], Conrel, [[Valero Energy Corporation|Diamond Shamrock]], [[Dow Corning]], [[DuPont]], [[FMC Corporation|FMC]], Glyco, [[Gulf Oil|Gulf]], MGK, [[Mobay]], [[Mobil]], [[Monsanto]], [[Edison (company)|Montedison]], [[Nissan Motor Company|Nissan]], Noram, [[Olin Corporation|Olin]], Penwalt, [[Procter & Gamble]], PPG, [[Sandoz]], [[Shell Oil Company|Shell]], Thompson-Hayward, [[United States Rubber Company|Uniroyal]], [[Upjohn]], [[Pacific Coast Borax Company|US Borax]], [[Genovique Specialties Corporation|Velsicol Chemical Company]], Vertac Chemical Corporation, and Zoecon, as well as the [[United States Army]], the Department of Defense, the Environmental Protection Agency, the Food and Drug Administration, the [[National Cancer Institute]], and the [[World Health Organization]].{{cite news | first = Bill | last = Richards | title = Wide Errors, Possible Fraud Found in Private Lab Testing | date = 1977-09-08 | work = The Washington Post | pages = 1, A11 }}{{cite web | url = http://nepis.epa.gov/Exe/ZyPURL.cgi?Dockey=91014ULV.txt | title = Summary of the IBT Review Program | accessdate = 2012-07-17 | date = July 1983 | work = Office of Pesticides and Toxic Substances | publisher = [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]]}}{{cite book | last1 = Jensen | first1 = Carl | author2= Project Censored| authorlink2 = Project Censored | title = 20 Years of Censored News | chapter = Fraudulent Safety Tests Deceive the American People | publisher = Seven Stories Press | year = 1997 | pages = 124 | isbn = 978-1888363524}} ==Associated substances== ===Polychlorinated biphenyls=== [[Eric Francis]] and [[Marie-Monique Robin]] have cited IBT's research into the safety of [[polychlorinated biphenyl]], which was not investigated, as also being potentially fraudulent.{{cite book | last1 = Robin | first1 = Marie-Monique | title = The World According to Monsanto: Pollution, Corruption, and the Control of the World's Food Supply | chapter = PCBs: White-Collar Crime | publisher = The New Press | year = 2010 | pages = 22 | isbn = 978-1595584267}} Philip Smith later testified on October 28, 1991, during a court case against Monsanto, that he had observed PCB data falsification during his employment as an assistant toxicologist at IBT. ''[[The Ecologist]]'' claimed in a 2007 article that IBT had provided [[expert witness|expert testimony]] against Douglas Gowan during a court case in which Monsanto allegedly sought to [[Defamation|discredit]] and [[Censorship|silence]] him over the wanton disposal of PCBs and other [[toxic waste]] at [[Brofiscin Quarry, Groes Faen]].{{cite news | first = Jon | last = Hughes |author2=Pat Thomas | title = Burying The Truth, the original Ecologist investigation into Monsanto and Brofiscin Quarry | date = 2007-10-11 | url = http://www.theecologist.org/The_Brofiscin_Monsanto_Files/777777/burying_the_truth.html | work = The Ecologist | accessdate = 2012-07-16}} ===Other=== In April, 1980 the Regina Leader-Post obtained and published a Canadian government list of more than 97 chemicals tested by IBT for which studies were considered "suspect". In June, 1980 an additional nine chemicals were added. According to Fagin and Lavelle in ''Toxic Deception'', Wright tampered with safety data for [[2,4-Dichlorophenoxyacetic acid|Machete]] and monosodium cyanurate, both Monsanto products.{{cite book | last1 = Fagin | first1 = Dan | last2 = Lavelle | first2 = Marianne | last3 = Center for Public Integrity | authorlink3 = Center for Public Integrity | title = Toxic Deception: How the Chemical Industry Manipulates Science, Bends the Law, and Endangers Your Health | publisher = Carol Publishing Group | year = 1996 | isbn = 978-1559723855}} IBT performed safety tests on [[Dinoseb]], which was later discovered to cause [[birth defect]]s and then pulled from the U.S. market in 1986.{{cite journal | title = EPA Pulls License of Pesticide OK'd on Phony Data | journal = Rachel's Environment & Health News | date = 1986-12-08 | first = Peter | last = Montague | issue = 2 | url = http://www.ejnet.org/rachel/rhwn002b.htm | accessdate = 2012-07-18}} IBT also originally evaluated the safety of [[atrazine]], a herbicide now thought to be an [[endocrine disruptor]], suspected [[carcinogen]], and possible [[teratogen]].{{cite news | last1 = Fagin | first1 = Dan | last2 = Lavelle | first2 = Marianne | last3 = Center for Public Integrity | authorlink3 = Center for Public Integrity | title = How Science Is Used as a Stall Tactic | date = 1997-02-25 | work = Newsday | location = Long Island, New York }}{{Cite journal | author = [[Frank Ackerman|Ackerman, Frank]] | title = The economics of atrazine | journal = International Journal of Occupational and Environmental Health | volume = 13 | issue = 4 | pages = 437–445 | year = 2007 | pmid = 18085057 | url = http://ase.tufts.edu/gdae/Pubs/rp/EconAtrazine.pdf | doi=10.1179/oeh.2007.13.4.437}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/23/us/23water.html?_r=1&hp=&pagewanted=all|title=Debating How Much Weed Killer Is Safe in Your Water Glass |last=Duhigg|first=Charles|date=2009-08-22|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=2009-09-10}} ==See also== *[[Contract research organization]] *[[Craven Laboratories]] *[[Good Laboratory Practice]] *[[Pesticide regulation in the United States]] * [[List of scientific misconduct incidents]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Further reading== *{{cite journal | title = The murky world of toxicity testing | journal = Science | date = 1983-06-10 | first = Eliot | last = Marshall | volume = 220 | issue = 4602 | pages = 1130–1132 | bibcode = 1983Sci...220.1130M | url = http://legacy.library.ucsf.edu/tid/lnn13c00/pdf | format = PDF | pmid=6857237 | doi=10.1126/science.6857237}} *{{cite court | litigants = Lloyd v. Industrial Bio-Test Laboratories, Inc | vol = 454 | reporter = F. Supp. | opinion = 807 | court = S.D.N.Y. | date = 1978-07-25 | url = https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=2019891680157398838}} *{{cite court | litigants = United States of America, Plaintiff-appellee, v. Joseph C. Calandra, Moreno Keplinger, Paul L. Wright, and James B. Plank, Defendants-appellants | vol = 706 | reporter = F.2d | opinion = 225 | court = 7th Cir. | date = 1983-05-03 | url = http://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/c/F2/706/706.F2d.225.83-1586.83-1583.html}} *{{cite court | litigants = United States of America, Plaintiff-appellee, v. Moreno L. Keplinger, Paul L. Wright, and James B. Plank, Defendants-appellants | vol = 776 | reporter = F.2d | opinion = 678 | court = 7th Cir. | date = 1985-10-29 | url = http://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F2/776/678/443220/}} {{Pesticide regulation in the United States}} [[Category:Defunct companies based in Illinois]] [[Category:Contract research organizations]] [[Category:Scientific misconduct]] [[Category:Northbrook, Illinois]]

revision.comment: /* Activities */ Since 2014,
revision.text:
{{Distinguish|International Code of Zoological Nomenclature}} {{Infobox organization |name = International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature |image = |image_border = |size = |alt = |caption = ICZN |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = ICZN |motto = |formation = {{start date and age|1895|9|18|df=yes}} |extinction = |type = [[International non-governmental organization]] |status = |purpose = |headquarters = |location = [[National University of Singapore]], [[Singapore]] |region_served = Worldwide |membership = |language = English, French |leader_title = President |leader_name = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://iczn.org/ Official ICZN website] |remarks = }}
The '''International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature''' ('''ICZN''') is an organization dedicated to "achieving stability and sense in the scientific naming of animals". Founded in 1895, it currently comprises 27 members from 19 countries,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://iczn.org/content/about-iczn|title=About the ICZN - International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature|publisher=}}</ref> mainly practicing zoological [[taxonomist]]s.<ref name="about">{{cite web|url=http://iczn.org/content/about-iczn|title=About the ICZN - International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature|publisher=}}</ref>
==Organization== The ICZN is governed by the "Constitution of the ICZN", which is usually published together with the [[ICZN Code]].<ref name="constitution">{{cite web|url=http://www.nhm.ac.uk/hosted-sites/iczn/code/index.jsp?nfv=&booksection=constitution|title=International Code of Zoological Nomenclature|publisher=}}</ref>
Members are elected by the Section of Zoological Nomenclature,<ref>[http://www.nhm.ac.uk/hosted-sites/iczn/code/index.jsp ICZN Code] Art. 77.3.1, [http://www.nhm.ac.uk/hosted-sites/iczn/code/includes/page.jsp?nfv=&booksection=constitution ICZN Constitution] Art. 3.1.1., 4.4.1, 4.5, 11.1.2, 16.1.3</ref> established by the [[International Union of Biological Sciences]] (IUBS).
The regular term of service of a member of the Commission is 6 years. Members can be re-elected up to a total of three full six-year terms in a row. After 18 continuous years of elected service, a break of at least 3 years is prescribed before the member can stand again for election.<ref>[http://www.nhm.ac.uk/hosted-sites/iczn/code/index.jsp?nfv=&booksection=constitution ICZN Constitution] Art. 3.1, 3.2</ref>
==Activities== Since 2014, the work of the Commission is supported by a small secretariat based at the [[National University of Singapore]], in [[Singapore]]. Previously, the secretariat was based in London and funded by the '''International Trust for Zoological Nomenclature'''.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://iczn.org/content/international-trust-zoological-nomenclature |title= International Trust for Zoological Nomenclature |publisher=ICZN |accessdate=4 October 2018}}</ref> The Commission assists the zoological community "through generation and dissemination of information on the correct use of the scientific names of animals".<ref name="about" />
The ICZN publishes the [[International Code of Zoological Nomenclature]] (usually referred to as "the Code" or "the ICZN Code"), a widely accepted [[Convention (norm)|convention]] containing the rules for the formal [[scientific name|scientific naming]] of all [[organism]]s that are treated as [[animal]]s. New editions of the Code are elaborated by the Editorial Committee appointed by the Commission.<ref>[http://www.nhm.ac.uk/hosted-sites/iczn/code/index.jsp ICZN Constitution] Art. 16.2</ref> The 4th edition of the Code (1999) was edited by seven people.<ref>W. D. L. Ride, H. G. Cogger, C. Dupuis, O. Kraus, A. Minelli, F. C. Thompson, P. K. Tubbs, as given in the ICZN Code 4th edition (printed version) p. IV.</ref>
The Commission also provides rulings on individual problems brought to its attention, as arbitration may be necessary in contentious cases, where strict adherence to the Code would interfere with stability of usage (e.g., see [[conserved name]]). These rulings are published in the '''''Bulletin of Zoological Nomenclature'''''.<ref name="about" /> Starting in 2017, volumes 65 (2008) onwards of the ''Bulletin'' will be available online to subscribers in the [[BioOne]] journal database.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.bioone.org/page/resources/institutions/new |title=Title additions & departures |publisher=BioOne |accessdate=31 August 2016}}</ref>
== See also == *[[International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.nhm.ac.uk/hosted-sites/iczn/code/index.jsp Text of the Code] * [http://www.zoobank.org ICZN ZooBank] * {{cite journal |author=ICZN |year=2008 |title=Proposed amendment of the ''International Code of Zoological Nomenclature'' to expand and refine methods of publication |journal=[[African Invertebrates]] |volume=49 |issue=2 |pages=1–11 |url=http://www.africaninvertebrates.org.za/ICZN_49_1_415.aspx |doi=10.5733/afin.049.0201}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:International Commission On Zoological Nomenclature}} [[Category:Zoological nomenclature]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1895]] [[Category:International scientific organizations]] [[Category:Naming organizations]]

page.title: International System of Electrical and Magnetic Units

revision.comment: punctuation style corrections
revision.text:
The '''International System of Electrical and Magnetic Units''' is an obsolete system of units used for measuring electrical and magnetic quantities. It was proposed as a system of practical international units by unanimous recommendation at the [[International Electrical Congress]] (Chicago, 1893), discussed at other Congresses, and finally adopted at the International Conference on Electric Units and Standards in London in 1908<ref name=eb11-p742/>. It was rendered obsolete by the inclusion of electromagnetic units in the [[International System of Units]] (SI) at the 9th [[General Conference on Weights and Measures]] in 1948. {{TOC right}}
==Earlier systems== The link between electromagnetic units and the more familiar units of [[length]], [[mass]] and [[time]] was first demonstrated by [[Carl Friedrich Gauss|Gauss]] in 1832 with his measurement of the Earth's magnetic field,<ref>{{citation | first = C. F. | last = Gauss | authorlink = Carl Friedrich Gauss | title = Intensitas vis magneticae terrestris ad mensuram absolutam revocata | journal = Commentationes Societatis Regiae Scientiarum Gottingensis Recentiores | volume = 8 | year = 1832–37 | pages = 3–44}}. [http://www.21stcenturysciencetech.com/translations/gaussMagnetic.pdf English translation].</ref> and the principle was extended to electrical measurements by [[Franz Ernst Neumann|Neumann]] in 1845.<ref>{{citation | first = F. E. | last = Neumann | authorlink = Franz Ernst Neumann | title = Allgemeine Gesetze der induciten elektrischen Ströme | year = 1847 | journal = Abhandlungen der Königlichen Preußischen Akademie der Wissenschaften zu Berlin : Aus dem Jahre 1845 | pages = 1–87 | access-date= 9 April 2018 | url = http://bibliothek.bbaw.de/bbaw/bibliothek-digital/digitalequellen/schriften/anzeige/index_html?band=07-abh/1845&seite:int=24}}; Reprinted: {{citation | chapter=Die mathematischen Gesetze der induciten elektrischen Ströme|title = Franz Neumanns gesammelte Werke | publisher = B. G. Teubner | location = Leipzig | year = 1912 | volume = 3 | pages = 257–344 || url = http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=umhistmath;idno=AAN8146.0003.001;cc=umhistmath}}.</ref><ref>{{citation | first = F. | last = Neumann | authorlink = Franz Ernst Neumann | title = Über ein allgemeines Princip der mathematischen Theorie inducirter elektrischer Ströme | year = 1849 | journal = Abhandlungen der Königlichen Preußischen Akademie der Wissenschaften zu Berlin : Aus dem Jahre 1847| pages = 1–71 |access-date=9 April 2018| url = http://bibliothek.bbaw.de/bbaw/bibliothek-digital/digitalequellen/schriften/anzeige/index_html?band=07-abh/1847&seite:int=27}}; Reprinted: {{citation | title = Franz Neumanns gesammelte Werke | publisher = B. G. Teubner | location = Leipzig | year = 1912 | volume = 3 | pages = 345–424 | url = http://quod.lib.umich.edu/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=umhistmath;idno=AAN8146.0003.001;cc=umhistmath}}.</ref> A complete system of metric electrical and magnetic units was proposed by [[Wilhelm Eduard Weber|Weber]] in 1851,<ref>{{citation | contribution = Weber, Wilhelm Eduard | title = Encyclopædia Britannica | volume = 28 | year = 1911 | edition = 11th | |url=https://archive.org/stream/encyclopaediabri28chisrich#page/458/mode/1up| page = 458}}</ref> based on the idea that electrical units could be defined solely in relation to absolute units of length, mass, and time.<ref>{{cite journal | first = W.E. | last = Weber | authorlink = Wilhelm Eduard Weber | title = Messungen galvanischer Leitungswiderstände nach einem absoluten Maaße | journal=Annalen der Physik und Chemie |year =1851 | volume=82|pages=337-369|url=http://reader.digitale-sammlungen.de/de/fs1/object/display/bsb10130395_00349.html}} Reprinted in: {{cite book|year=1893| url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-662-24693-1_9|url-access=subscription|title=Wilhelm Weber's Werke|pages=276-300|doi=10.1007/978-3-662-24693-1_9|publisher=Springer}} and {{cite journal |journal=Annalen der Physik | volume=158 | title=Messungen galvanischer Leitungswiderstände nach einem absoluten Maasse | url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/andp.18511580302 |url-access=subscription|doi=10.1002/andp.18511580302}} English translation: {{cite journal |journal=Philosophical Magazine | title=On the Measurement of Electric Resistance according to an absolute Standard|volume=22, Fourth Series| pages=226-240 and 261-269|translator=E. Atkinson|url=https://archive.org/stream/londonedinburg4221861lond#page/226/mode/2up}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=G.C.F. |first1= |date=1891 |title=Wilhelm Eduard Weber |url= |journal=Nature |volume=44 |issue= |pages=230 |doi=10.1038/044229b0 |access-date= }}</ref> Weber's original proposal was based on a millimetre–milligram–second system of units.
The development of the electric telegraph (an invention of Gauss and Weber) demonstrated the need for accurate electrical measurements. At the behest of [[William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin|Thomson]],<ref name=eb11-p740>{{cite encyclopedia | contribution = Units, Physical | title = Encyclopædia Britannica | volume = 27 | year = 1911 | edition = 11th |url=https://archive.org/stream/encyclopaediabri27chisrich#page/740/mode/1up| pages = 740}}</ref> the [[British Association for the Advancement of Science]] (B.A.) set up a committee in 1861, initially to examine standards for electrical resistance,<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |url=https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/93052#page/43/mode/1up |title= Recommendations adopted by the General Committee at the Manchester meeting in September 1861 |pages=xxxix-xl|encyclopedia= Report of the Thirty-First meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science |location=London| publisher = John Murray | year = 1862 }}</ref> which was expanded in 1862 to include other electrical standards.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |url=https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/93054#page/41/mode/1up |title= Recommendations adopted by the General Committee at the Cambridge meeting in October 1862 |pages=xxxix|encyclopedia= Report of the Thirty-Second meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science |location=London| publisher = John Murray | year = 1863 }}</ref> After two years of discussion, experiment and considerable differences of opinion,<ref name=eb11-p740/> the committee decided to adapt Weber's approach to the [[CGS system]] of units,<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |url=https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/item/93073#page/189/mode/1up |title= Report of the General Committee appointed by the British Association on Standards of Electrical Resistance |pages=111-176|encyclopedia= Report of the Thirty-Third Meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science |location=London| publisher = John Murray | year = 1864 }}</ref> but used metre, gramme and second as their absolute units. However these units were both difficult to [[Realisation (metrology)|realize]] and (often) impractically small.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | contribution = Units, Physical | title = Encyclopædia Britannica | volume = 27 | year = 1911 | edition = 11th |url=https://archive.org/stream/encyclopaediabri27chisrich#page/740/mode/1up| pages = 743}}</ref> To overcome these handicaps, the B.A. also proposed a set of "practical" or "reproduceable" units, which were not directly linked to the CGS system but which were, as near as experimental accuracy allowed, equal to multiples of the corresponding CGS units.<ref name=eb11-p741>{{cite encyclopedia | contribution = Units, Physical | title = Encyclopædia Britannica | volume = 27 | year = 1911 | edition = 11th |url=https://archive.org/stream/encyclopaediabri27chisrich#page/741/mode/1up| pages = 741}}</ref> The B.A. had developed ''two'' sets of CGS units. The practical units were based on the [[Centimetre gram second system of units#Electromagnetic units (EMU)|electromagnetic set of units]] rather than the [[electrostatic units|electrostatic set]].<ref name=eb11-p741/>
==1893 system== The B.A. system of practical units gained considerable international support, and was adopted – with one important modification – by the [[International Exposition of Electricity|First International Conference of Electricians]] (Paris, 1881). The British Association had constructed an artefact representation of the ohm (a standard length of resistance wire which had a resistance of 10<sup>9</sup> CGS units of electric resistance, that is one ohm) whereas the international conference preferred a method of [[Realisation (metrology)|realization]] that could be repeated in different laboratories in different countries. The chosen method was based on the [[resistivity]] of [[mercury (element)|mercury]], by measuring the resistance of a column of mercury of specified dimensions (106 cm × 1 mm<sup>2</sup>): however, the chosen length of column was almost 3 millimetres too short, leading to a difference of 0.28% between the new practical units and the CGS units which were supposedly their basis.<ref>{{citation | title = ohm | url = http://www.sizes.com/units/ohm.htm | publisher = sizes.com | accessdate = 2010-08-11}}.</ref>
The anomaly was resolved at another international conference, in Chicago in 1893, by a correction in the definition of the ohm. The units agreed at this conference were termed "international" units, to distinguish them from their predecessors.
The 1893 system had three base units: the international [[ampere]], the international [[ohm]] and the international [[volt]].
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Unit ! 1893 ("international") definition<ref group="Note" name="update">The terminology of some of the definitions has been updated to modern usage.</ref> ! CGS ("absolute") equivalent ! Notes |- | [[Ampere]] | the unvarying [[electric current|current]] which, when passed through a solution of [[silver nitrate]] in water, deposits [[silver]] at the rate of {{nowrap|0.001 118 00 grams}} per second | the current produced in a conductor with a 1 ohm resistance when there is a potential difference of 1 volt between its ends | 0.1 cgs units of electric current |- | [[Ohm]] | the [[electric resistance|resistance]] offered to an unvarying [[electric current]] by a column of [[mercury (element)|mercury]] at the temperature of melting ice 14.4521 grams in mass, of a constant cross-sectional area and of the length of 106.3 centimetres | | 10<sup>9</sup> cgs units of electric resistance |- | [[Volt]] | {{frac|1000|1434}} of the [[electromotive force]] of a [[Clark cell]] at a temperature of 15 °C | the electromotive force produced in an [[electric circuit]] which cuts 10<sup>8</sup> magnetic lines of force per second | 10<sup>8</sup> cgs units of electromotive force |-{{cite journal |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |title= |url= |journal= |volume= |issue= |pages= |doi= |access-date= }} |}
The international units did not have the same formal legal status as the [[metre]] and the [[kilogram]] through the [[Metre Convention]] (1875), although several countries adopted the definition within their national laws (e.g., the United States, through Public Law 105 of July 12, 1894<ref>{{cite journal |author=T.C. Mendenhall |date=1895 |title=Legal Units of Electric Measure |journal=Science |volume=1 |issue= |pages=9-15 |jstor=1623949 }}</ref>).
==Overdefinition and the 1908 modification== The 1893 system of units was overdefined, as can be seen from an examination of [[Ohm's law]]: :[[Electric potential difference|''V'']] = [[Electric current|''I'']][[Electric resistance|''R'']] By Ohm's law, knowing any two of the physical quantities ''V'', ''I'' or ''R'' (potential difference, current or resistance) will define the third, and yet the 1893 system defines the units for all three quantities. With improvements in measurement techniques, it was soon recognised that
:1 V<sub>int</sub> ≠ 1 A<sub>int</sub> × 1 Ω<sub>int</sub>.
The solution came at an international conference in London in 1908. The essential point was to reduce the number of base units from three to two by redefining the international volt as a derived unit. There were several other modifications of less practical importance:<ref name=eb11-p742>{{cite encyclopedia | contribution = Units, Physical | title = Encyclopædia Britannica | volume = 27 | year = 1911 | edition = 11th |url=https://archive.org/stream/encyclopaediabri27chisrich#page/742/mode/1up| pages = 742}}</ref>
*the international ampere and the international ohm were formally defined in terms of the corresponding [[Centimetre gram second system of units#Electromagnetic units (EMU)|CGS electromagnetic units]], with the 1893 definitions retained as preferred [[Realisation (metrology)|realizations]]; *the preferred realization of the international volt was in terms of the electromotive force of a [[Weston cell]] at 20 °C (1.0184 V<sub>int</sub>), as this type of cell has a lower temperature coefficient than the Clark cell; *several other derived units for use in electrical and magnetic measurements were formally defined:<ref group="Note" name="update"/> ;International [[Coulomb]]:the [[electric charge]] transferred by a current of one international ampere in one second;<ref group="Note" name="CF">The [[coulomb]] and the [[farad]] had been used in earlier B.A. systems of electrical units with slightly different definitions, hence the need to add the qualifier "international".</ref> ;International [[Farad]]:the [[capacitance]] of a [[capacitor]] charged to a potential of one international volt by one international coulomb of electricity;<ref group="Note" name="CF"/> ;[[Joule]]:10<sup>7</sup> units of [[work (physics)|work]] in the CGS system, represented sufficiently well for practical use by the energy expended in one second by an international ampere in an international ohm; ;[[Watt]]:10<sup>7</sup> units of [[power (physics)|power]] in the CGS system, represented sufficiently well for practical use by the work done at the rate of one joule per second; ;[[Henry (unit)|Henry]]:the [[inductance]] in a circuit when an electromotive force induced in this circuit is one international volt, while the inducing current varies at the rate of one ampere per second.
==SI units== With advances in the theory of [[electromagnetism]] and in [[quantity calculus]], it became apparent that a coherent absolute system of units could only include one electromagnetic [[Base unit (measurement)|base unit]]. The first such system was proposed by [[Giovanni Giorgi|Giorgi]] in 1901:<ref name="EB11">{{citation | contribution = Units, Physical | title = Encyclopædia Britannica | volume = 27 | year = 1911 | edition = 11th | pages = 738–45}}.</ref><ref name="IEC">{{citation | title = Giovanni Giorgi | url = http://www.iec.ch/about/history/figures/giovanni_giorgi.htm | publisher = International Electrotechnical Commission | accessdate = 2014-02-21}}.</ref><ref>{{citation | last = Giorgi | first = G. | authorlink = Giovanni Giorgi | title = Rational Units of Electromagnetism}}. [http://www.iec.ch/about/history/documents/documents_giovanni.htm Original manuscript with handwritten notes by Oliver Heaviside].</ref> it used the [[ohm]] as the additional base unit in the [[MKS system]], and so is often referred to as the MKSΩ system or the Giorgi system.
An additional problem with the CGS system of electrical units, pointed out as early as 1882 by [[Oliver Heaviside]],<ref>{{cite journal| last = Heaviside | first = O. | authorlink = Oliver Heaviside | title = The Relations between Magnetic Force and Electric Current | journal = The Electrician | issue = 18 November |page=6 | year = 1882 |url=https://archive.org/stream/electricalpapers01heavuoft#page/194/mode/2up}}.</ref> was that they were not "rationalized", that is they failed to properly take account of [[permittivity]] and [[Permeability (electromagnetism)|permeability]] as properties of a medium. Giorgi was also a great proponent of rationalization of the electrical units.<ref name="IEC"/>
The choice of electrical unit for the base unit in a rationalized system depends only on practical considerations, particularly the ability to [[Realisation (metrology)|realize]] the unit accurately and reproducibly. The [[ampere]] rapidly gained support over the ohm, as many national standards laboratories were already realizing the ampere in absolute terms using [[ampere balance]]s.<ref name="EB11"/><ref>{{citation | first = R. T. | last = Glazebrook | authorlink = Richard Glazebrook | title = The fourth unit of the Giorgi system of electrical units | year = 1936 | journal = Proc. Phys. Soc. | volume = 48 | pages = 452 | doi = 10.1088/0959-5309/48/3/312}}.</ref> The [[International Electrotechnical Commission]] (IEC) adopted the Giorgi system with the ampere replacing the ohm in 1935, and this choice of base units is often called the MKSA system.<ref name="IEC"/>
The [[International Committee for Weights and Measures]] (CIPM) approved a new set of definitions for electrical units, based on the rationalized MKSA system, in 1946, and these were internationally adopted under the [[Metre Convention]] by the 9th [[General Conference on Weights and Measures]] in 1948.<ref>{{SIbrochure8th|page=144}}.</ref> Under this system, which would become the [[International System of Units]] (SI), the ohm is a derived unit.<ref group="Note">The ohm is the electric resistance between two points of a conductor when a constant potential difference of 1 volt, applied to these points, produces in the conductor a current of 1 ampere, the conductor not being the seat of any electromotive force.</ref>
The SI definitions of the electrical units are formally equivalent to the 1908 international definitions, and so there should not have been any change in the size of the units. Nevertheless, the international ohm and the international volt were not usually realized in absolute terms but by reference to a standard resistance and a standard electromotive force respectively. The realizations recommended in 1908 are not exactly equivalent to the absolute definitions: recommended conversion factors<ref>{{GreenBook2nd|page=114}}.</ref> are :1 Ω<sub>int</sub> ≈ 1.000 49 Ω :1 V<sub>int</sub> ≈ 1.000 34 V although slightly different factors may apply for individual standards in national measurement laboratories.<ref group="Note">Conversion factors for the U.S. national standards (NIST) are 1 Ω<sub>int</sub> = {{nowrap|1.000 495 Ω}} and 1 V<sub>int</sub> = {{nowrap|1.000 330 V}}.</ref> As the international ampere was usually realized by means of an ampere balance rather than electrolytically,<ref name="EB11"/> 1 A<sub>int</sub> = 1 A. The conversion factor for the "electrolytic" ampere (A<sub>elec</sub>) can be calculated from modern values of the [[atomic weight]] of [[silver]] and the [[Faraday constant]]: :1 A<sub>elec</sub> = 1.000 022(2) A
==See also== *[[Conventional electrical units]]
==Notes and references==
===Notes=== {{reflist|group=Note}}
===References=== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://www.sizes.com/units/int_ENMsys.htm Sizes.com]
[[Category:Units of measurement|*]] [[Category:Metrology]] [[Category:History of electrical engineering]]

revision.comment: [[Wikipedia:OABOT|Open access bot]]: add pmc identifier to citation with #oabot.
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=May 2018}}
'''Intuitive statistics''', or '''folk statistics''', refers to the cognitive phenomenon where organisms use data to make generalizations and predictions about the world. This can be a small amount of sample data or training instances, which in turn contribute to [[Inductive reasoning|inductive inferences]] about either population-level properties, future data, or both. Inferences can involve revising hypotheses, or beliefs, in light of probabilistic data that inform and motivate future predictions. The informal tendency for cognitive animals to intuitively generate statistical inferences, when formalized with certain [[Probability axioms|axioms of probability]] theory, constitutes [[statistics]] as an academic discipline.
Because this capacity can accommodate a broad range of informational domains, the subject matter is similarly broad and overlaps substantially with other cognitive phenomena. Indeed, some have argued that "cognition as an intuitive statistician" is an apt companion metaphor to the computer metaphor of cognition.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book |title=Cognition as intuitive statistics |last=Gigerenzer |first=Gerd |last2=Murray |first2=David J. |isbn=9781138950221 |location=London |publisher=Psychology Press |year=2015 |oclc=918941179}}</ref> Others appeal to a variety of statistical and probabilistic mechanisms behind theory construction<ref name=":15">{{Cite journal |last=Gopnik |first=Alison |last2=Tenenbaum |first2=Joshua B. |date= May 2007 |title=Bayesian networks, Bayesian learning and cognitive development |journal=Developmental Science|volume=10|issue=3|pages=281–287|doi=10.1111/j.1467-7687.2007.00584.x|issn=1363-755X}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gopnik|first=Alison|date= August 2011 |title=The Theory Theory 2.0: Probabilistic Models and Cognitive Development |journal=Child Development Perspectives |volume=5 |issue=3 |pages=161–163 |doi=10.1111/j.1750-8606.2011.00179.x |issn=1750-8592}}</ref> and category structuring.<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":16" /> Research in this domain commonly focuses on generalizations relating to number, relative frequency, risk, and any systematic signatures in inferential capacity that an organism (e.g., humans, or non-human primates) might have.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":9">{{Cite book |title=Cognition and chance : the psychology of probabilistic reasoning |last=Nickerson |first=Raymond S. |date=2004 |publisher=Lawrence Erlbaum Associates |isbn=9780805848991 |location=Mahwah, N.J. |oclc=56115142}}</ref>
== Background and theory == Intuitive inferences can involve generating hypotheses from incoming sense data, such as [[categorization]] and [[concept]] structuring.
